calculated cutaneous vascular resistance increased significantly. 4. Eight 
subjects performed mental arithmetic for two periods of 2 min separated by a 
rest period of 2 min. By the end of the second minute of each period of mental 
arithmetic there was a significant decrease in erythrocyte flux. Mean arterial 
pressure increased significantly in the first period only, but calculated 
cutaneous vascular resistance increased in both periods, consistent with 
cutaneous vasoconstriction.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

DOI: 10.1042/cs0790043
PMID: 2167789 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Cutaneous vascular responses evoked in the hand by the cold pressor test and by mental arithmetic.
Citation: Marriott, I., Marshall, J. M., & Johns, E. J. (1990). Cutaneous vascular responses evoked in the hand by the cold pressor test and by mental arithmetic. Clinical Science (London), 79(1), 43-50.
conclusion neutral: placing the right hand in water at 20 degrees C for 2 min induced a significant decrease in cutaneous erythrocyte flux in the contralateral hand and a significant fall in mean arterial pressure... Subesequent immersion of the right hand in water at 0-4 degrees C for 2 min caused a significant decrease in erythrocyte flux in the contralateral hand and a significant rise in mean arterial pressure. It is concluded that the cold pressor response evoked from one hand elicited a substantial reflex vasoconstriction in the skin of the other hand; accordingly, calculated cutaneous vascular resistance increased significantly.
exclusion reason: cold water (and cold pressor) exposure was used solely as a diagnostic stimulus to study vascular responses, not for its therapeutic or physiological benefit.
sentiment_exp: The abstract doesn't discuss any health benefits or harms of cold water immersion—it's focused on studying the body’s response to cold as a diagnostic tool, not as a therapy.
sex_representation_exp: The study doesn't specify the sex of participants, nor does it report results separately for men and women.
summary: This research investigates how briefly dipping a hand in cold water changes blood flow and pressure in the other hand, using this as a way to study the body’s reflexes, rather than to test any health effects of cold immersion.

abstract:
403. Am Rev Respir Dis. 1990 Jun;141(6):1516-21. doi: 10.1164/ajrccm/141.6.1516.

Effect of codeine on the sensations elicited by loaded breathing.

Supinski G(1), Dimarco A, Bark H, Chapman K, Clary S, Altose M.

Author information:
(1)Cleveland-Metropolitan General Hospital, Department of Medicine, Ohio 44109.

The present study examined the effect of codeine, a centrally acting opiate, on 
the respiratory sensations elicited in normal subjects by breathing to 
exhaustion against externally applied inspiratory threshold loads. Subjects were 
tested on two separate days following the double-blind, randomized 
administration of either placebo or codeine (90 mg). The intensity of the 
sensations of effort and discomfort experienced during two loaded breathing 
trials (a "high" load that was 73% of the maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) and 
a "low" load that was 63% of the MIP) was evaluated using category (Borg) scores 
on each day of study. To verify that the dosage of codeine administered was 
sufficient to produce analgesia, we also determined the effect of this dosage on 
the time that subjects could tolerate immersion of one hand in ice water. 
Codeine altered neither the perceived effort nor the sense of discomfort 
associated with breathing against external loads and had no appreciable effect 
on the time to exhaustion during loaded breathing trials. This dose of codeine 
did, however, increase the time that ice water immersion could be tolerated and 
reduced the rate at which the sense of discomfort increased over time during ice 
water trials. These results indicate that, provided the pressure-time index of 
respiratory muscle contraction remains constant, analgesic doses of codeine 
alter neither the sensations elicited by loaded breathing nor the total time 
that breathing against a fatiguing inspiratory load can be tolerated.

DOI: 10.1164/ajrccm/141.6.1516
PMID: 2350094 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Effect of codeine on the sensations elicited by loaded breathing.
Citation: Supinski, G., Dimarco, A., Bark, H., Chapman, K., Clary, S., & Altose, M. (1990). Effect of codeine on the sensations elicited by loaded breathing. American Review of Respiratory Disease, 141(6), 1516-1521.
conclusion neutral: Codeine altered neither the perceived effort nor the sense of discomfort associated with breathing against external loads and had no appreciable effect on the time to exhaustion during loaded breathing trials.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: The results showed no advantages or disadvantages of cold water immersion itself; it was only used to test pain tolerance as a side effect of codeine, not as a therapy.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract doesn't specify how many women or men participated, nor does it break down results by sex.
summary: This study explored whether codeine changes how people feel during tough breathing exercises. Cold water was used as a way to measure pain tolerance, not for its own therapeutic effect, so it doesn't provide new information about cold water immersion for health or wellness.

abstract:
404. Kosm Biol Aviakosm Med. 1990 Mar-Apr;24(2):41-6.

[Effectiveness and mechanisms of the protective action of sidnocarb in 
experimental weightlessness and cooling].

[Article in Russian]

Lakota NG, Kvasova MM, Larina IM, Vorob'ev DV, Ostrovskaia GZ.

Twenty-one subjects took part in experiments with acute cooling (maximally 
allowable time for swimming in ice-cold water and two-day exposure to winter 
field conditions) or two-day exposure to microgravity (simulated by water 
immersion). They were divided into a placebo group (5, 5 and 6 man-exposures) 
and a sydnocarb group (6, 6 and 4 man-exposures) and examined by biochemical, 
radioimmune and radioligand methods. It was found that physiological responses 
to cold and microgravity effects as well as sydnocarb were similar. During cold 
exposures the thermal steady-state was achieved by taking maximum daily doses of 
the drug. In thermoneutral water immersion body temperature fall was controlled 
by therapeutic doses of the drug. Body temperature decline beginning with 
immersion day 2 can be related to the endogenous decline of heat production due 
to a new functioning level which is well known in gravitational physiology, i. 
e. this is the effect of microgravity per se. With respect to old and new 
information about the pharmacological properties of sydnocarb, mechanisms of its 
high thermoregulatory effects on CNS structures responsible for heat production 
and heat loss are discussed.

PMID: 1973202 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: [Effectiveness and mechanisms of the protective action of sidnocarb in experimental weightlessness and cooling]
Citation: Lakota, N. G., Kvasova, M. M., Larina, I. M., Vorob'ev, D. V., & Ostrovskaia, G. Z. (1990). [Effectiveness and mechanisms of the protective action of sidnocarb in experimental weightlessness and cooling]. Kosmicheskaia Biologiia i Aviakosmicheskaia Meditsina, 24(2), 41-46.
conclusion neutral: Physiological responses to cold and microgravity effects as well as sydnocarb were similar. During cold exposures the thermal steady-state was achieved by taking maximum daily doses of the drug.
exclusion reason: focus is on evaluating the effects of sydnocarb drug in conditions of cooling and simulated microgravity, not on the therapeutic or physiological effects of cold water immersion alone
sentiment_exp: The study didn't show unique benefits or harms from cold water immersion itself; instead, it examined how a drug (sydnocarb) affects body temperature during cold exposure and simulated weightlessness. The study's focus isn't on the effects of cold water immersion therapy.
sex_representation_exp: The study included 21 participants but did not specify how many were men or women, or whether results were analyzed by sex.
summary: This research looked at how a drug called sydnocarb influences body temperature in people exposed to cold water and simulated weightlessness, rather than investigating the independent effects of cold water immersion. As such, it doesn't provide direct insights into the benefits or risks of cold water immersion for health.

abstract:
405. Fundam Clin Pharmacol. 1990;4(2):141-6. doi: 10.1111/j.1472-8206.1990.tb00481.x.

Action of neurotropin on cold-induced pain in normal volunteers: a double-blind 
placebo study.

Thiebauld C(1), Vandeput J, Lintermans J, Vandenbosch P.

Author information:
(1)Centre de Médecine Avancée, Brussels, Belgium.

The analgesic action of neurotropin, a biological compound widely used in Japan 
with a record of very limited side-effects, was tested in 8 Caucasian normal 
volunteers. For the pain test, the subjects were requested to immerse the right 
hand in ice-cold water and to report the appearance of the following sensations: 
pain threshold (PThr) and tolerance to pain (PTol). Pain sensitivity range (PSR) 
was calculated by difference between PThr and PTol expressed in s from beginning 
of immersion. Neurotropin tablets or an indistinguishable inert placebo were 
administered according to a randomized double-blind cross-over design and their 
influence in the pain test was investigated during 2 daily sessions. The effects 
of both treatments were assessed by calculating the difference between initial 
and post-medication values for each pain response parameter. Under placebo the 
means of all effects were found to be negative, reflecting the appearance of 
hyperalgesia under repetitive pain conditions, with neurotropin, the effects on 
PTol and PSR were positive and significantly different from those of placebo. 
These results are discussed in terms of possible mechanisms of action: 
neurotropin analgesic activity could be linked to its kinin release-inhibiting 
properties or to a reduction in vaso-constriction and hyperalgesia related to an 
effect on catecholamines.

DOI: 10.1111/j.1472-8206.1990.tb00481.x
PMID: 2351364 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Action of neurotropin on cold-induced pain in normal volunteers: a double-blind placebo study.
Citation: Thiebauld, C., Vandeput, J., Lintermans, J., & Vandenbosch, P. (1990). Action of neurotropin on cold-induced pain in normal volunteers: a double-blind placebo study. Fundamental & Clinical Pharmacology, 4(2), 141-146.
conclusion neutral: Under placebo the means of all effects were found to be negative, reflecting the appearance of hyperalgesia under repetitive pain conditions, with neurotropin, the effects on PTol and PSR were positive and significantly different from those of placebo.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus, not to examine the physiological or therapeutic effects of cold water immersion itself.
sentiment_exp: The research used cold water simply to create pain and tested the effect of a drug, not the effect of immersion itself, so it doesn't indicate if cold water immersion has helpful or harmful effects.
sex_representation_exp: The study included 8 people, but didn't specify how many were women or whether results were analyzed by sex.
summary: This study looked at a pain medication during a cold-water pain test, not at the effects of cold water immersion itself.

abstract:
406. J Appl Physiol (1985). 1989 Dec;67(6):2466-72. doi: 
10.1152/jappl.1989.67.6.2466.

Free fatty acid availability and temperature regulation in cold water.

Martineau L(1), Jacobs I.

Author information:
(1)Defence and Civil Institute of Environmental Medicine, North York, Ontario, 
Canada.

The purpose of this study was to investigate whether a reduced availability of 
plasma free fatty acids (FFA) would impair human temperature regulation during 
cold exposure. Seven seminude male subjects were immersed on two occasions in 18 
degrees C water for 90 min or until their rectal temperature (Tre) decreased to 
35.5 degrees C. The immersion occurred after 2 h of intermittent oral ingestion 
of either nicotinic acid (NIC) or a placebo (PLAC). Plasma FFA levels 
immediately before the immersion were significantly lower in NIC (87 +/- 15 
mumol/l) than in PLAC (655 +/- 116 mumol/l, P less than 0.05). Although FFA 
levels increased by 73% in NIC during the immersion (P less than 0.05), they 
remained significantly lower than in PLAC (151 +/- 19 vs. 716 +/- 74 mumol/l, P 
less than 0.05) throughout the immersion. Muscle glycogen concentrations in the 
vastus lateralis decreased after cold water immersion in both trials (P less 
than 0.05), but the rate of glycogen utilization was similar, averaging 1.00 +/- 
0.27 mmol glucose unit.kg dry muscle-1.min-1). Plasma glucose levels were 
significantly reduced after immersion in both trials (P less than 0.05), this 
decrease being greater in NIC (1.3 +/- 0.2 mmol/l) than in PLAC (0.7 +/- 0.1 
mmol/l, P less than 0.05). O2 uptake increased to 3.8 +/- 0.3 times preimmersion 
values in both trials (P less than 0.05). Mean respiratory exchange ratio (RER) 
immediately before the immersion was greater in NIC (0.87 +/- 0.02) than in PLAC 
(0.77 +/- 0.01, P less than 0.05). Cold exposure increased RER in PLAC but not 
in NIC.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

DOI: 10.1152/jappl.1989.67.6.2466
PMID: 2606855 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Free fatty acid availability and temperature regulation in cold water.
Citation: Martineau, L., & Jacobs, I. (1989). Free fatty acid availability and temperature regulation in cold water. Journal of Applied Physiology, 67(6), 2466-2472.
conclusion neutral: the rate of glycogen utilization was similar, averaging 1.00 +/- 0.27 mmol glucose unit.kg dry muscle-1.min-1); Plasma glucose levels were significantly reduced after immersion in both trials (P less than 0.05), this decrease being greater in NIC (1.3 +/- 0.2 mmol/l) than in PLAC (0.7 +/- 0.1 mmol/l, P less than 0.05).
sentiment_exp: The study didn't find clear benefits or harms from cold water immersion on temperature regulation, even with changes in free fatty acid availability. Results suggest the process didn't make things better or worse overall.
sex_representation_exp: Only men participated in this study, and results were not reported separately by sex. Women were not included.
summary: Researchers tested if lowering blood fat levels with a drug would make it harder for people to regulate their body temperature in cold water. They found that, despite lower fat availability, muscle fuel use and oxygen consumption remained similar, so reducing fatty acids didn't significantly affect how the body coped with cold water.

abstract:
407. Gut. 1989 Nov;30(11):1530-9. doi: 10.1136/gut.30.11.1530.

Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal transit and antroduodenal motility by 
experimentally applied stress: the role of beta-adrenoreceptor mediated 
pathways.

O'Brien JD(1), Thompson DG, Day SJ, Burnham WR, Walker E.

Author information:
(1)Department of Gastroenterology, London Hospital Medical College.

A series of three experiments were performed on healthy adult volunteers to 
investigate the possible role played by beta-adrenoreceptor mediated pathways in 
the disturbance of human upper intestinal motor function by hand immersion in 
cold water. In the first experiment, (an extended pilot study on one 
individual), orocaecal transit of a standard meal was measured on 36 occasions 
with and without cold water stimulation and with and without a series of alpha 
and beta blocking drugs. Cold water stimulation consistently delayed transit in 
this individual, an effect which was attenuated by prior beta-blockade. In a 
double blind trial of the effect of beta-blocker atenolol v placebo on transit 
in nine individuals, a consistent reduction in the cold water induced transit 
delay was observed (p less than 0.01) independent of any direct effect of 
beta-blockade. In the third experiment seven individuals underwent repeated 
studies of antroduodenal pressure activity comparing the effects of cold and 
warm water stimulation with and without beta blockade to determine whether the 
observed transit effect could be related to an action on gastrointestinal 
motility. Cold water stimulation reduced antroduodenal motility, but no 
consistent effects of previous beta blockade were noted. These studies indicate 
the presence of a beta-adrenoreceptor mediated pathway in the cold water induced 
delay of orocaecal transit but not in the inhibition of gastroduodenal motility. 
Further studies are indicated to determine the site and mode of action of this 
transit effect more precisely.

DOI: 10.1136/gut.30.11.1530
PMCID: PMC1434332
PMID: 2557268 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal transit and antroduodenal motility by experimentally applied stress: the role of beta-adrenoreceptor mediated pathways.
Citation: O'Brien, J. D., Thompson, D. G., Day, S. J., Burnham, W. R., & Walker, E. (1989). Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal transit and antroduodenal motility by experimentally applied stress: the role of beta-adrenoreceptor mediated pathways. Gut, 30(11), 1530-1539.
conclusion negative: Cold water stimulation consistently delayed transit in this individual, an effect which was attenuated by prior beta-blockade. Cold water stimulation reduced antroduodenal motility.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as an experimentally applied stressor, not as a therapeutic or physiological intervention relevant to public health
sentiment_exp: The study found that cold water immersion of the hand caused a delay in gastrointestinal transit and a reduction in motility, suggesting an undesirable or stressful physiological response rather than a therapeutic one.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract does not specify the sex of participants or whether results were analyzed separately by sex.
summary: Researchers tested how immersing a hand in cold water (used here as a method to create stress) affects how quickly food moves through the gut and how the stomach and intestine muscles work. They found that this kind of stress slows gut movement and reduces motility, but it was not done as a therapeutic intervention with wider health benefits.

abstract:
408. Pain. 1989 Jun;37(3):305-313. doi: 10.1016/0304-3959(89)90195-4.

The cold pressor pain paradigm in children: feasibility of an intervention model 
(Part II).

Zeltzer LK(1), Fanurik D, LeBaron S.

Author information:
(1)Division of Hematology/Oncology, Children's Hospital of Los Angeles, and 
Division of Child Development and Biobehavioral Pediatrics, Department of 
Pediatrics, UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CAU.S.A. University of 
Alabama, Tuscaloosa, ALU.S.A. University of Calgary, Faculty of Medicine, 
Calgary, AlbertaCanada.

The purpose of this study was to examine the feasibility of testing a 
psychological approach (hypnosis) to pain reduction in children using the cold 
pressor paradigm. Children's pain ratings at 10 sec intervals and duration of 
arm immersion (40 sec maximum) in 15 degrees C (n = 37) and 12 degrees C water 
(n = 29) were assessed in 6-12-year-old children during 2 baseline trials 
(alternating arms), followed by 2 more trials after randomization to a control 
or hypnosis treatment condition. Hypnosis was found to reduce pain significantly 
more than the control condition in both 15 degrees C and 12 degrees C water. 
Hypnotic susceptibility was not strongly related to hypnotic pain reduction. 
However, age was significant, with younger children showing higher pain ratings 
and early arm withdrawal rates and less response to hypnosis than older 
children. In 15 degrees C water, females had higher pain ratings and early 
withdrawal rates than males, but this sex discrepancy disappeared in 12 degrees 
C water. This study demonstrated the feasibility of the cold pressor paradigm 
for testing intervention strategies and its potential for enhancing our 
understanding of pain in children.

DOI: 10.1016/0304-3959(89)90195-4
PMID: 2755712 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: The cold pressor pain paradigm in children: feasibility of an intervention model (Part II).
Citation: Zeltzer, L. K., Fanurik, D., & LeBaron, S. (1989). The cold pressor pain paradigm in children: feasibility of an intervention model (Part II). Pain, 37(3), 305-313.
conclusion neutral: This study demonstrated the feasibility of the cold pressor paradigm for testing intervention strategies and its potential for enhancing our understanding of pain in children.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: The study didn't focus on health or physiological effects of cold water immersion, but rather used it as a way to induce pain in order to study hypnosis. No benefit or harm from cold water immersion itself was the focus.
sex_representation_exp: Both boys and girls were included, and results pointed out some sex differences in pain response at certain temperatures.
summary: The research used cold water immersion to create a controlled pain stimulus in children, but its purpose was to test psychological methods for pain reduction, not to investigate cold water’s health effects. So, it doesn't help us understand how cold water immersion might directly benefit or harm children.

abstract:
409. Dig Dis Sci. 1988 May;33(5):614-8. doi: 10.1007/BF01798366.

Effects of rest, stress, and food on myoelectric spiking activity of left and 
sigmoid colon in humans.

Schang JC(1), Devroede G, Hébert M, Hémond M, Pilote M, Devroede L.

Author information:
(1)Department of Surgery, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire, Sherbrooke, Quebec, 
Canada.

The great variability which is known to affect colonic motility may partly be 
the result of changes in physiological conditions. In order to test this 
hypothesis, 40 subjects were sequentially put in conditions of vigilance, rest, 
stress, and feeding while colonic motility was monitored. The myoelectric 
spiking activity of the left colon was recorded with a 50-cm-long silastic tube 
equipped with four bipolar ring electrodes (located 10 cm apart) introduced into 
the left colon by flexible sigmoidoscopy. Tracings were performed while the 
subjects were kept awake (by conversation) for 1 hr, put at rest (quiet) for 
another 1 hr, submitted to a stress (by alternatively immersing and removing one 
hand from 2-4 degrees C cold water) for 20 min, and finally recorded for 2 hr 
after a 800-kcal meal. In 18 other subjects, the sequences of vigilance and rest 
were randomized. The results showed that colonic spiking activity was made of 
sporadic bursts that are known to be associated with intraluminal propulsion and 
of stationary bursts that probably play no role in colonic peristalsis. The 
duration of sporadic spiking activity was respectively 13.6 +/- 1.2 min/hr (mean 
+/- SEM) during the period of vigilance, 5.4 +/- 0.6 min/hr during the period of 
rest (P less than 0.001), 14.3 +/- 1.0 min/hr during the period of stress (NS), 
and 16.8 +/- 1.2 min/hr after a meal (P less than 0.05). The duration of 
stationary spiking activity did not change significantly throughout the four 
periods, respectively, 6.6 +/- 4.9, 4.4 +/- 3.7 (NS), 5.2 +/- 3.9 (NS), and 3.3 
+/- 2.8 min/hr (NS).(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

DOI: 10.1007/BF01798366
PMID: 3359913 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Effects of rest, stress, and food on myoelectric spiking activity of left and sigmoid colon in humans.
Citation: Schang, J. C., Devroede, G., Hébert, M., Hémond, M., Pilote, M., & Devroede, L. (1988). Effects of rest, stress, and food on myoelectric spiking activity of left and sigmoid colon in humans. Digestive Diseases and Sciences, 33(5), 614-618.
Demographic: healthy adult volunteers (exact specifics not stated)
conclusion neutral: The duration of sporadic spiking activity was respectively 13.6 +/- 1.2 min/hr (mean +/- SEM) during the period of vigilance, 5.4 +/- 0.6 min/hr during the period of rest (P less than 0.001), 14.3 +/- 1.0 min/hr during the period of stress (NS), and 16.8 +/- 1.2 min/hr after a meal (P less than 0.05). The duration of stationary spiking activity did not change significantly throughout the four periods, respectively, 6.6 +/- 4.9, 4.4 +/- 3.7 (NS), 5.2 +/- 3.9 (NS), and 3.3 +/- 2.8 min/hr (NS).
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as an acute stressor (pain/cold pressor test) rather than for therapeutic or physiological adaptation
sentiment_exp: There was no significant difference in colon activity during cold-induced stress compared to vigilance, and the study did not demonstrate any benefit or harm related to cold water immersion.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract does not mention the sex of participants or whether men and women were analyzed separately.
summary: This research looked at how the colon's muscle activity changes during rest, stress (using a cold-water hand immersion), and after eating. However, the cold water was used to create temporary stress, not as a deliberate therapy, so it's not relevant for understanding the health effects of cold water immersion.

abstract:
410. Pain. 1988 May;33(2):241-251. doi: 10.1016/0304-3959(88)90096-6.

The efficacy of hypnosis- and relaxation-induced analgesia on two dimensions of 
pain for cold pressor and electrical tooth pulp stimulation.

Houle M(1), McGrath PA, Moran G, Garrett OJ.

Author information:
(1)Pain Research Program, Faculty of Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, 
London, Ont. N6A 5C2 Canada Child Health Research Institute, Department of 
Pediatrics, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5C2 Canada 
Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5C2 
Canada.

This study evaluated the efficacy of hypnosis- and relaxation-induced 
suggestions for analgesia for reducing the strength and unpleasantness 
dimensions of pain evoked by noxious tooth pulp stimulation and by cold pressor 
stimulation. The Tellegen Absorption Questionnaire was used to assess hypnotic 
susceptibility for 28 subjects in order to match treatment groups according to 
sex and susceptibility scores. Tooth pulp stimulation consisted of a 1 sec train 
of 1 msec pulses at a frequency of 100 Hz, applied at 20 sec intervals to the 
central incisor. Six stimuli, selected between subject's pain and tolerance 
thresholds, were presented 3 times each in random order. Cold pressor 
stimulation consisted of forearm immersion in a circulating water bath 
maintained at 0-1 degrees C. Subjects made threshold determinations of pain and 
tolerance and used Visual Analogue Scales to rate the strength and the 
unpleasantness of both noxious stimuli before and after receiving either 
hypnosis- or relaxation-induced analgesia. There were no significant differences 
in pain reductions between hypnosis- and relaxation-induced interventions. 
However, the percent reduction in both strength and unpleasantness varied 
significantly as a function of the type of pain. Both hypnosis and relaxation 
significantly reduced the strength and the unpleasantness of tooth pulp 
stimulation, but only the unpleasantness dimension of cold pressor pain. The 
pain reductions were not correlated with subjects' hypnotic susceptibility 
levels. The results indicate that the extent and the quality of the analgesia 
produced by these cognitive-based therapies vary not only according to subjects' 
characteristics and the efficacy of the intervention, but also according to the 
nature of the noxious stimuli. Tooth pulp and cold pressor stimulation represent 
qualitatively different stimuli with respect to both the type of nerves 
activated and the mode of stimulus application. Discrete, randomly presented 
levels of noxious electrical stimulation to the teeth activate predominantly 
small fibers and produce brief pain sensations that vary unpredictably in 
intensity. In contrast, continuous cold stimulation to the forearm activates a 
variety of nociceptive and non-nociceptive fibers and produces progressive cold 
and pain sensations with a predictable increase in intensity from cold 
sensations to paresthesia and severe pain.

DOI: 10.1016/0304-3959(88)90096-6
PMID: 3288942 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: The efficacy of hypnosis- and relaxation-induced analgesia on two dimensions of pain for cold pressor and electrical tooth pulp stimulation.
Citation: Houle, M., McGrath, P. A., Moran, G., & Garrett, O. J. (1988). The efficacy of hypnosis- and relaxation-induced analgesia on two dimensions of pain for cold pressor and electrical tooth pulp stimulation. Pain, 33(2), 241-251.
Demographic: healthy volunteers (not explicitly stated, but implied by the recruitment for pain experiments without mention of clinical conditions)
conclusion neutral: There were no significant differences in pain reductions between hypnosis- and relaxation-induced interventions. [...] Both hypnosis and relaxation significantly reduced the strength and the unpleasantness of tooth pulp stimulation, but only the unpleasantness dimension of cold pressor pain.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: This abstract doesn't focus on therapeutic or physiological effects of cold water immersion, but instead uses it as a way to induce pain for testing hypnosis and relaxation, so there is no relevant benefit or harm related to cold water immersion itself.
sex_representation_exp: Although groups were matched by sex, the total number of women is not specified, and the results are not reported separately for men and women.
summary: This study isn't about the health effects of cold water immersion, but rather uses cold water to induce pain and compares how suggestions of hypnosis and relaxation affect people's pain experiences. It's not relevant to understanding the health or recovery benefits of cold water immersion.

abstract:
411. Acta Med Scand. 1988;223(5):431-5. doi: 10.1111/j.0954-6820.1988.tb15894.x.

Responsiveness to diving reflex after acute myocardial infarction. Influence of 
early beta-adrenoceptor blocker therapy.

Olsson G(1), Rehnqvist N, Ekman AM.

Author information:
(1)Department of Internal Medicine, Karolinska Institute, Danderyd Hospital, 
Sweden.

We studied the influence of beta-adrenoceptor blockade on heart rate responses 
to facial immersion in ice-cooled water after acute myocardial infarction. Forty 
patients with acute myocardial infarction were randomized to the double-blind 
therapy with metoprolol 200 mg daily or matching placebo. Therapy was started as 
soon as possible after admission to hospital and continued for 15 days. After 
this initial period all patients were treated with beta-blockade during the 
subsequent 6 months. Repeated investigations of heart rate responses to facial 
immersion in ice-cooled water and 24-hour ECG-recordings were performed on day 
15 (while patients were on study therapy), after 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months. 
Throughout the 6-month period, facial immersion elicited significant heart rate 
reductions in both treatment groups. No differences were found between the two 
groups or between different examinations during follow-up. There was no 
correlation between heart rate response to facial immersion and frequency of 
ventricular arrhythmia on a 24-hour monitoring. In conclusion, acute 
administration of metoprolol in myocardial infarction does not influence the 
bradycardial response to facial immersion either in the early postinfarction 
phase or during 6 months' follow-up. There is no relation between bradycardial 
response to face immersion and frequency of ventricular arrhythmias.

DOI: 10.1111/j.0954-6820.1988.tb15894.x
PMID: 2897764 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Responsiveness to diving reflex after acute myocardial infarction. Influence of early beta-adrenoceptor blocker therapy.
Citation: Olsson, G., Rehnqvist, N., & Ekman, A. M. (1988). Responsiveness to diving reflex after acute myocardial infarction. Influence of early beta-adrenoceptor blocker therapy. Acta Medica Scandinavica, 223(5), 431-435.
conclusion neutral: No differences were found between the two groups or between different examinations during follow-up. There was no correlation between heart rate response to facial immersion and frequency of ventricular arrhythmia on a 24-hour monitoring. In conclusion, acute administration of metoprolol in myocardial infarction does not influence the bradycardial response to facial immersion either in the early postinfarction phase or during 6 months' follow-up. There is no relation between bradycardial response to face immersion and frequency of ventricular arrhythmias.
exclusion reason: cold water facial immersion used only as a diagnostic stimulus for the diving reflex, not for therapeutic or physiological effects of whole-body cold water immersion
sentiment_exp: The researchers found no meaningful differences or benefits related to cold water facial immersion and didn't link it to better or worse health outcomes.
sex_representation_exp: We don't know how many women took part or if the results were analyzed by sex, as this was not reported.
summary: This study looks at how people who've had a heart attack react to having their face immersed in cold water, but it's focused on a diagnostic test (the diving reflex) rather than using cold water immersion as a treatment.

abstract:
412. Eur J Clin Pharmacol. 1988;34(3):267-71. doi: 10.1007/BF00540954.

Effects of intra-arterial ketanserin in Raynaud's phenomenon assessed by 
99MTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy.

Kunnen JJ(1), Dahler HP, Doorenspleet JG, van Oene JC.

Author information:
(1)Department of Anaesthesiology, Bethesda Hospital, Hoogeveen, The Netherlands.

The severity of the peripheral vasopastic condition in 10 patients with 
Raynaud's phenomenon was investigated using scintigraphy of both hands. 
99MTc-pertechnetate was used as a diffusable tracer and scintigrams were 
recorded with normal hand skin temperature and following immersion of the hands 
in ice-cold water. Cold provocation resulted in a marked reduction of the rate 
of blood inflow and tissue perfusion in affected hands. The selective peripheral 
S2-antagonist ketanserin and placebo were administered intra-arterially 
according to a double-blind cross-over design. As compared to placebo, 
ketanserin significantly improved the rate of inflow following cold provocation, 
and it increased tissue perfusion in the hands of the patients to values 
normally observed in healthy individuals. The results support the use of 
ketanserin in the treatment of Raynaud's phenomenon.

DOI: 10.1007/BF00540954
PMID: 2840293 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Effects of intra-arterial ketanserin in Raynaud's phenomenon assessed by 99MTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy.
Citation: Kunnen, J. J., Dahler, H. P., Doorenspleet, J. G., & van Oene, J. C. (1988). Effects of intra-arterial ketanserin in Raynaud's phenomenon assessed by 99MTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy. European Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 34(3), 267-271.
conclusion neutral: Cold provocation resulted in a marked reduction of the rate of blood inflow and tissue perfusion in affected hands.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a diagnostic/provocation tool, not for therapeutic or physiological effect
sentiment_exp: The study only examined how cold water affected blood flow as a way to test patients with Raynaud's phenomenon, not as a treatment or therapy.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract doesn't specify how many men or women were included, nor does it say whether results were split by sex.
summary: This study used ice-cold water immersion just to provoke symptoms and measure blood flow changes in Raynaud's patients. It doesn't tell us anything about the health benefits or harms of cold water immersion therapy.

abstract:
413. Br J Clin Pharmacol. 1987 Dec;24(6):823-6. doi: 
10.1111/j.1365-2125.1987.tb03253.x.

Dipipanone and nifedipine in cold induced pain; analgesia not due to skin 
warming.

Holland RL(1), Harkin NE, Coleshaw SR, Jones DA, Peck AW, Telekes A.

Author information:
(1)Wellcome Research Laboratories, Beckenham, Kent.

The mechanism of the pain relief produced by opiates in normal volunteers in the 
cold induced pain test has been investigated. In a double-blind placebo 
controlled study, hand skin temperature during a 3 min immersion in water at 1 
degree C was not affected by either the opioid dipipanone 8 mg or the 
vasodilator nifedipine 10 and 20 mg. During this immersion, dipipanone produced 
significant pain relief. Nifedipine reduced pre-immersion blood pressures and 
raised heart rates, however, it did not significantly alter pain scores. It is 
concluded that vasodilatation and local warming do not play a role in the relief 
of pain by opiates in the cold immersion test.

DOI: 10.1111/j.1365-2125.1987.tb03253.x
PMCID: PMC1386411
PMID: 2894219 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Dipipanone and nifedipine in cold induced pain; analgesia not due to skin warming.
Citation: Holland, R. L., Harkin, N. E., Coleshaw, S. R., Jones, D. A., Peck, A. W., & Telekes, A. (1987). Dipipanone and nifedipine in cold induced pain; analgesia not due to skin warming. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 24(6), 823-826.
conclusion neutral: It is concluded that vasodilatation and local warming do not play a role in the relief of pain by opiates in the cold immersion test.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: The study found that cold water was used to test pain but didn't focus on the health effects of immersion itself, so no benefits or harms related to cold water immersion were reported.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract calls the participants 'normal volunteers,' but doesn’t specify how many were men or women, or report results by sex.
summary: In this study, cold water immersion was only used as a way to induce pain so researchers could test how well certain drugs relieve it. The therapeutic or physiological effects of immersion itself were not addressed.

abstract:
414. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 1986 Mar;39(3):353-7. doi: 10.1038/clpt.1986.52.

The influence of intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and beta-1 receptor 
selectivity on the recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling in 
normotensive subjects.

Lenders JW, Salemans J, de Boo T, Lemmens WA, Thien T, van't Laar A.

A double-blind randomized study was designed to investigate differences in the 
recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling during dosing with 
placebo or one of four beta-blockers: propranolol, atenolol, pindolol, and 
acebutolol. In 11 normotensive nonsmoking subjects, finger skin temperature was 
measured with a thermocouple before and 20 minutes after immersion of one hand 
in a water bath at 16 degrees C. This finger cooling test caused no significant 
changes in systemic hemodynamics such as arterial blood pressure, heart rate, 
and forearm blood flow. The recovery of finger skin temperature during 
propranolol dosing was better than that during pindolol and atenolol dosing. 
There were no differences between the recoveries of skin temperature during 
pindolol, atenolol, and acebutolol dosing. Thus we could demonstrate no 
favorable effect of intrinsic sympathomimetic activity or beta 1-selectivity on 
the recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling.

DOI: 10.1038/clpt.1986.52
PMID: 2868824 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: The influence of intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and beta-1 receptor selectivity on the recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling in normotensive subjects.

The influence of intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and beta-1 receptor selectivity on the recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling in normotensive subjects. Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics, 39(3), 353-357.
conclusion neutral: Thus we could demonstrate no favorable effect of intrinsic sympathomimetic activity or beta 1-selectivity on the recovery of finger skin temperature after finger cooling.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a diagnostic/provocation tool, not to assess therapeutic or physiological effects

sex_representation_exp: The abstract does not specify whether men or women participated, nor does it report any analyses by sex.
summary: In this small study, cold water immersion was used to test how quickly the skin recovers from cold with different medications; it wasn't meant to examine the health or therapeutic effects of cold water immersion itself, so its results aren't relevant to the intended topic.

abstract:
415. J Behav Med. 1986 Feb;9(1):89-96. doi: 10.1007/BF00844647.

Comparison of behavioral treatments for Raynaud's disease.

Jobe JB, Sampson JB, Roberts DE, Kelly JA.

Induced vasodilation by classical conditioning was compared to biofeedback 
therapy as treatment for idiopathic Raynaud's disease. Classical conditioning 
therapy consisted of 54 10-min immersions of both hands in water (43 degrees C) 
simultaneously with whole-body exposure to cold air (0 degrees C), given three 
times per day, 3 days per week, for 6 weeks. Biofeedback therapy consisted of 
eight sessions of electromyograph feedback (frontalis) while listening to 
relaxation tapes, followed by 10 sessions of digital thermal feedback while 
listening to relaxation tapes. Both groups received 10-min cold stress tests of 
whole-body exposure to 0 degrees C before and after treatments. Results 
indicated that both therapies significantly increased the digital temperature 
response to cold. Although no differences between classical conditioning and 
biofeedback were found at the end of training, a 1-year follow-up indicated that 
classical conditioning was more effective.

DOI: 10.1007/BF00844647
PMID: 3701861 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Comparison of behavioral treatments for Raynaud's disease.
Citation: Jobe, J. B., Sampson, J. B., Roberts, D. E., & Kelly, J. A. (1986). Comparison of behavioral treatments for Raynaud's disease. Journal of Behavioral Medicine, 9(1), 89-96.
conclusion positive: Results indicated that both therapies significantly increased the digital temperature response to cold.
conclusion neutral: Although no differences between classical conditioning and biofeedback were found at the end of training, a 1-year follow-up indicated that classical conditioning was more effective.
exclusion reason: heated water immersion (43°C) was used; not a study of cold water immersion
sentiment_exp: Although the study reports improved digital temperature response (a benefit), the therapy used hot water immersion, not cold water immersion. Therefore, the sentiment does not apply to cold water immersion.
sex_representation_exp: The study does not mention how many men or women participated, nor does it report outcomes separately by sex.
summary: This study compared two therapies for Raynaud's disease using hot water hand immersions, not cold water immersion. Because heated water was used, the findings aren't relevant to the benefits or risks of cold water immersion for health.

abstract:
416. Indian J Physiol Pharmacol. 1986 Jan-Mar;30(1):1-10.

Beta-adrenoceptor blockade and cardiovascular response to the cold pressor test.

Dikshit MB, Patrick JM.

Seven healthy subjects immersed a hand in random order in either warm water or 
in cold water at 5 degrees C for 2 min, after taking orally a single dose of 120 
mg of propranolol or a placebo in a double blind fashion. The cold stress 
resulted in a significant increase in blood pressure and the rate pressure 
product without a change in heart rate. Beta-adrenoceptor blockade did not 
affect the pressor response the cold. The changes induced by the cold stress in 
the cardiovascular variables in the placebo and propranolol experiments were not 
statistically different. The highest rate pressure product during the cold 
pressor test was about 109 units. This was well below the pain threshold value 
of about 200 found during exercise in patients with ischaemic heart disease. In 
the recovery phase, the cardiovascular variables reverted to pre-immersion 
values within 1 min inspite of continued low hand skin temperature.

PMID: 3818024 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Beta-adrenoceptor blockade and cardiovascular response to the cold pressor test.
Citation: Dikshit, M. B., & Patrick, J. M. (1986). Beta-adrenoceptor blockade and cardiovascular response to the cold pressor test. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacology, 30(1), 1-10.
conclusion neutral: Beta-adrenoceptor blockade did not affect the pressor response to the cold. The changes induced by the cold stress in the cardiovascular variables in the placebo and propranolol experiments were not statistically different.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain or cardiovascular stress test, not to study therapeutic, physiological, or hormonal effects
sentiment_exp: The study found that cold water stress increased blood pressure, but taking propranolol did not change this response. The results indicate there wasn't a beneficial or harmful effect—just no significant difference.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract does not specify the sex of participants, and results were not reported separately by sex.
summary: In this experiment, people put their hand in cold water briefly to test how their heart and blood pressure reacted, both with and without a heart medication. The researchers weren't studying any health or therapeutic benefits of cold water immersion, so this study doesn't tell us anything about using cold water therapy for recovery, performance, or wellness.

abstract:
417. J Lab Clin Med. 1985 Nov;106(5):534-41.

Thromboxane A2 and prostacyclin do not modulate the systemic hemodynamic 
response to cold in humans.

Gresele P, Bounameaux H, Arnout J, Perez-Requejo JL, Deckmyn H, Vermylen J.

The immersion of a limb in a mixture of water and ice induces in normal humans 
an initial vasoconstriction mediated mainly by catecholamine release. In some 
studies the cold pressor test was associated with an increase in vasoconstrictor 
thromboxane A2 and in vasodilating prostacyclin. Dazoxiben hydrochloride, a 
thromboxane synthase inhibitor, has been reported to suppress cold-induced 
vasoconstriction. We compared in a double-blind, crossover, placebo-controlled 
study the effects of indomethacin (a cyclooxygenase inhibitor), dazoxiben 
hydrochloride, and BM13.177 (a novel thromboxane receptor antagonist) on the 
changes in cutaneous vascular resistance and arterial blood pressure induced by 
cold in 12 healthy volunteers. Cold challenge produced an increase in blood 
pressure and an initial decrease in finger blood flow, reflecting an increase in 
cutaneous vascular resistance. Neither effective suppression of thromboxane A2 
generation or of the effects of thromboxane A2 on platelets by the three active 
treatments nor increase in prostacyclin generation after ingestion of dazoxiben 
hydrochloride modified the hemodynamic response to cold. In conclusion, 
thromboxane A2 and prostacyclin do not play a significant role in the modulation 
of the systemic hemodynamic response to cold. In addition, thromboxane receptor 
antagonism in normal humans does not influence basal blood pressure.

PMID: 2932514 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Thromboxane A2 and prostacyclin do not modulate the systemic hemodynamic response to cold in humans.
Citation: Gresele, P., Bounameaux, H., Arnout, J., Perez-Requejo, J. L., Deckmyn, H., & Vermylen, J. (1985). Thromboxane A2 and prostacyclin do not modulate the systemic hemodynamic response to cold in humans. Journal of Laboratory and Clinical Medicine, 106(5), 534-541.
conclusion neutral: thromboxane A2 and prostacyclin do not play a significant role in the modulation of the systemic hemodynamic response to cold. In addition, thromboxane receptor antagonism in normal humans does not influence basal blood pressure.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a diagnostic or experimental stimulus, not for therapeutic or physiological/hormonal benefit
sentiment_exp: The researchers found that neither the prostaglandins nor their inhibitors changed the body's basic responses to cold exposure, meaning cold water immersion didn't show benefit or harm here.
sex_representation_exp: It is not clear how many women participated, and results were not reported separately by sex.
summary: This study tested whether certain blood chemicals affect how the body reacts to cold water, but found that blocking these chemicals didn't change the body's basic physical response. The experiment used cold limb immersion purely as a test and not as a health treatment, so it's not directly relevant to understanding the health benefits or risks of cold water immersion therapy.

abstract:
418. Clin Sci (Lond). 1985 Jan;68(1):49-56. doi: 10.1042/cs0680049.

Evidence of parasympathetic activity of the angiotensin converting enzyme 
inhibitor, captopril, in normotensive man.

Campbell BC, Sturani A, Reid JL.

Captopril (50 mg orally) produced a significant fall in systolic and diastolic 
blood pressure in six normotensive sodium replete subjects, without a rise in 
heart rate. On captopril, there was no change in the expected normal increase in 
heart rate on standing. Supine plasma noradrenaline was not reduced by captopril 
and normal postural increases were maintained. Atropine (0.04 mg/kg i.v.) 
reduced the difference in blood pressure change between captopril and placebo. 
Facial immersion in water produced a bradycardia. This change was abolished by 
atropine and attenuated both by captopril and edrophonium (10 mg i.v.), a 
cholinesterase inhibitor. Lying down after 6 min standing produced an immediate 
transient tachycardia, which was abolished by atropine and attenuated by 
captopril. Blood pressure and heart rate rose after a cold pressor test on both 
captopril and placebo. The tachycardia during the Valsalva manoeuvre was 
inhibited by edrophonium and to a lesser extent by captopril. The effects of 
captopril and edrophonium were additive. Parasympathetic activity of captopril 
may contribute to its haemodynamic profile.

DOI: 10.1042/cs0680049
PMID: 3880523 [Indexed for MEDLINE]

419. Eur Heart J. 1983 May;4 Suppl C:123-9. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/4.suppl_c.123.

Calcium entry blocking agents in digital vasospasm (Raynaud's phenomenon).

Kahan A, Weber S, Amor B, Menkes CJ, Saporta L, Hodara M, Guerin F, Degeorges M.

We have evaluated the therapeutic effect of the calcium entry blocking agent 
nifedipine in Raynaud's phenomenon associated with connective tissue diseases 
and in idiopathic digital vasospasm. In a preliminary study 16 patients with a 
digital vasospasm that could be induced by hand-immersion in cold water (4 
degrees C) were challenged a second time with cold water 1 and 6h after 20 mg 
oral nifedipine. Nifedipine provided an effective protection against this 
cold-induced vasospasm in 14 of the 16 patients. Thirty patients were included 
in a short-term ambulatory study: Raynaud's phenomenon was associated with 
progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) in 10 patients, systemic lupus 
erythematosus (SLE) in five and rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in three; it was 
idiopathic (I) in 12 patients. Each patient received, in a double-blind manner 
and random order, on two consecutive weeks, nifedipine (20 mg three times daily) 
and placebo. Nifedipine proved to be effective: the mean number of digital 
vasospastic attacks per week decreased from 27.3 to 5.8 (P less than 0.01). The 
results in the SLE and RA groups were similar and were pooled. The improvement 
(in % decrease) was better in the idiopathic group (90.9) than in the SLE and RA 
group (78.6, P less than 0.02) and the PSS group (64.0, P less than 0.01).

DOI: 10.1093/eurheartj/4.suppl_c.123
PMID: 6352267 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Calcium entry blocking agents in digital vasospasm (Raynaud's phenomenon).
Citation: Kahan, A., Weber, S., Amor, B., Menkes, C.J., Saporta, L., Hodara, M., Guerin, F., & Degeorges, M. (1983). Calcium entry blocking agents in digital vasospasm (Raynaud's phenomenon). European Heart Journal, 4(Suppl C), 123–129.
Demographic: Patients with Raynaud's phenomenon (associated with connective tissue diseases or idiopathic)
conclusion neutral: "In a preliminary study 16 patients with a digital vasospasm that could be induced by hand-immersion in cold water (4 degrees C) were challenged a second time with cold water 1 and 6h after 20 mg oral nifedipine... Nifedipine provided an effective protection against this cold-induced vasospasm in 14 of the 16 patients."
exclusion reason: cold water immersion was used only as a method to induce vasospasm (pain stimulus), not as a therapeutic intervention or for evaluating its physiological/therapeutic/hormonal effects
sentiment_exp: The study does not assess the effects of cold water immersion itself, but rather uses it as a way to provoke symptoms for testing the effectiveness of a drug treatment.
sex_representation_exp: The study does not specify how many women were included or whether results were analyzed separately by sex.
summary: This research looked at using cold water to trigger vasospasm in patients with Raynaud's phenomenon, so that they could test the effects of a medication. It does not provide evidence about the physiological or therapeutic effects of cold water immersion itself.

abstract:
420. Gut. 1983 Apr;24(4):277-83. doi: 10.1136/gut.24.4.277.

Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal function by cold stress.

Thompson DG, Richelson E, Malagelada JR.

To study the effects of stressful stimulus (cold pain) upon postprandial 
gastric, duodenal, and pancreatic function, nine healthy adult volunteers were 
intubated and then given two identical liquid meals, (199 cal (789 KJ) 240 ml), 
each being ingested during a period of irregular fasting gastroduodenal 
motility. Ten minutes after each meal the subjects received, in randomised 
order, either a test or control stimulus. The test stimulus consisted of 
repeated one minute immersions of a hand into ice water, with 15 seconds 
recovery between immersions, for a total of 20 minutes, while for the control, 
water at 37 degrees C was used. Serial samples of gastric and duodenal contents 
allowed estimation of changes in gastric emptying and acid secretion, together 
with pancreatic trypsin output, by a double marker perfusion technique. 
Measurements of blood pressure, pulse, and finger temperature acted as 
extra-intestinal indices of autonomic response to the stimuli. Cold pain 
significantly delayed gastric emptying and produced a biphasic alteration in 
both gastric secretion and pancreatic trypsin output, with an initial reduction 
during the response to the stress followed by an increase during the post-stress 
period. Our findings show that the normal postprandial function of the upper gut 
can be measurably disturbed by a stressful stimulus. The coincidence of these 
disturbances with other extra-intestinal autonomic changes suggests that they 
are a further manifestation of the somatic response to a stress.

DOI: 10.1136/gut.24.4.277
PMCID: PMC1419959
PMID: 6832623 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal function by cold stress.
Citation: Thompson, D. G., Richelson, E., & Malagelada, J. R. (1983). Perturbation of upper gastrointestinal function by cold stress. Gut, 24(4), 277-283.
conclusion negative: Cold pain significantly delayed gastric emptying and produced a biphasic alteration in both gastric secretion and pancreatic trypsin output, with an initial reduction during the response to the stress followed by an increase during the post-stress period.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: Because the cold water exposure was mainly to cause stress and led to negative effects like delayed digestion, its impact is interpreted as negative.
sex_representation_exp: The sex of the participants and whether results were split by men and women was not specified.
summary: This research looked at how placing a hand in ice water affects digestion, but used cold as a stressful pain stimulus rather than a therapeutic or recovery measure. The cold exposure made digestion slower and disrupted stomach and pancreatic function, suggesting stress-related harms rather than any intended health benefit.

abstract:
421. Br J Clin Pharmacol. 1982 Dec;14(6):867-70. doi: 
10.1111/j.1365-2125.1982.tb02051.x.

Effects of cold exposure on blood pressure, heart rate and forearm blood flow in 
normotensives during selective and non-selective beta-adrenoceptor blockade.

Houben H, Thien T, Wijnands G, Van't Laar A.

Haemodynamic effects of a cold pressor test (foot immersion for 6 min in water 
at 5 degrees C) without medication and after the non-selective beta-adrenoceptor 
blocker propranolol and the selective beta-adrenoceptor blocker metoprolol were 
studied in 17 volunteers. In the control study as well as in the study with the 
beta-adrenoceptor blockers cold exposure caused comparable changes, namely a 
blood pressure rise and a reduction of forearm blood flow. The increase in heart 
rate during cold exposure was clearly and equally reduced by both 
beta-adrenoceptor blockers. Plasma noradrenaline rose significantly by 47%, 
plasma adrenaline did not change. It is concluded, that as to this kind of 
stress, beta 1-selective-adrenoceptor blockade confers no important advantage 
over non-selective beta-adrenoceptor blockade.

DOI: 10.1111/j.1365-2125.1982.tb02051.x
PMCID: PMC1427543
PMID: 6129886 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Effects of cold exposure on blood pressure, heart rate and forearm blood flow in normotensives during selective and non-selective beta-adrenoceptor blockade.
Citation: Houben, H., Thien, T., Wijnands, G., & Van't Laar, A. (1982). Effects of cold exposure on blood pressure, heart rate and forearm blood flow in normotensives during selective and non-selective beta-adrenoceptor blockade. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 14(6), 867-870.
conclusion neutral: In the control study as well as in the study with the beta-adrenoceptor blockers cold exposure caused comparable changes, namely a blood pressure rise and a reduction of forearm blood flow. The increase in heart rate during cold exposure was clearly and equally reduced by both beta-adrenoceptor blockers. Plasma noradrenaline rose significantly by 47%, plasma adrenaline did not change. It is concluded, that as to this kind of stress, beta 1-selective-adrenoceptor blockade confers no important advantage over non-selective beta-adrenoceptor blockade.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain/stress stimulus (cold pressor test), not for therapeutic or physiological benefit.
sentiment_exp: The study doesn't discuss benefits or harms of cold water immersion itself; instead, it only reports physiological effects during a stress test without implying therapeutic value.
sex_representation_exp: The study doesn’t specify how many men or women participated, and it doesn't report any sex-based findings.
summary: This research looked at how cold foot immersion affected blood pressure and heart rate, mainly to test the effects of certain heart medications. The cold exposure served as a stress test rather than as a form of therapy, so it's not relevant for advice about the health benefits or risks of cold water immersion.

abstract:
422. Rev Rhum Mal Osteoartic. 1982 Apr;49(5):337-43.

[Controlled study of nifedipine in the treatment of Raynaud's phenomenon].

[Article in French]

Kahan A, Weber S, Amor B, Saporta L, Hodara M, Degeorges M.

In each of the 16 patients included in our first study [6 idiopathic Raynaud's 
phenomenon (I), 4 associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and 6 with 
progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS)] digital vasospasm could be reproduced by 
immersion of both hands in cold water (4 degree C). Each patient received in a 
double-blind manner and random order on two consecutive days, the 
calcium-channel blocking agent nifedipine (20 mg) and placebo. Nifedipine 
protection against vasospasm provoked by cold water (4 degrees C) was considered 
good or excellent in 14 of the 16 patients (p less than 0.001 versus placebo). 
In the second study, 30 patients [12 I, 10 PSS, 5 SLE and 3 rheumatoid arthritis 
(RA)] received in a double blind manner and random order, on two consecutive 
weeks, nifedipine (20 mg 3 time daily) and placebo. The improvement with 
nifedipine (in percentage of the decrease of the number of vasospastic attacks) 
was 90.95 in the 1 group, 78.63 SLE and RA and 64.02 in PSS (p less than 0.01). 
An open study during 3 months has confirmed the effectiveness of nifedipine (10 
mg 3 times daily). The improvement was 88.92 in the 1 group, 76.33 in SLE and RA 
and 59.16 in PSS, 7 out of 30 patients stopped the treatment because of side 
effects (headache, flush, nausea, oedema of the ankles). Thus nifedipine appears 
to be extremely useful in the treatment of Raynaud's phenomenon.

PMID: 6285445 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: [Controlled study of nifedipine in the treatment of Raynaud's phenomenon]
Citation: Kahan, A., Weber, S., Amor, B., Saporta, L., Hodara, M., & Degeorges, M. (1982). [Controlled study of nifedipine in the treatment of Raynaud's phenomenon]. Rev Rhum Mal Osteoartic, 49(5), 337-343.
Demographic: Patients with Raynaud's phenomenon (idiopathic, associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, progressive systemic sclerosis, or rheumatoid arthritis)
conclusion neutral: digital vasospasm could be reproduced by immersion of both hands in cold water (4 degree C)
exclusion reason: cold water immersion was used solely as a diagnostic/provocative tool, not as a therapeutic intervention
sentiment_exp: The cold water immersion was used only to trigger vasospasm for testing drug effectiveness, and not as a treatment itself. No beneficial or harmful effects of cold water immersion are evaluated.
sex_representation_exp: The study does not specify the sex or gender of the participants, nor does it analyze data by sex.
summary: In this research, cold water immersion was simply used to provoke symptoms of Raynaud's phenomenon so that the effectiveness of a medication (nifedipine) could be tested. The study does not look at any therapeutic or health effects of cold water itself, so it isn't relevant for understanding the impact of cold water immersion on health or recovery.

abstract:
423. Aviat Space Environ Med. 1981 Sep;52(9):517-22.

Thermal and glycemic responses during mild exercise in +5 to -15 degrees C 
environments following alcohol ingestion.

Graham TE.

Male volunteers (3 groups of 6) were tested once after drinking alcohol (alc) 
and once after consuming a placebo. The subject drank 2.5 ml of 40% alc/kg in 30 
min and, wearing a sweat suit, entered an environmental chamber (+5 degrees, -5 
degrees, or -15 degrees C; one group at each temperature). Intermittent, bicycle 
exercise was performed for 3 h (40% VO2 max, 20 min work--10 min rest repeated 6 
times). Peak blood alc (11.87 +/- 0.82 mM/occurred at 87.4 +/- 7.5 min; there 
were no differences between the three temperature groups. Based on pulmonary VO2 
and RQ, neither environmental temperature nor alcohol affected metabolism, but 
blood glucose was significantly (p less than 0.05) lower with alcohol from 105 
min until the end of the 3 h. Mean body temp was lower (p less than 0.05) in the 
-15 degrees C group and alcohol resulted in lower (p less than 0.05) body 
temperature in all three groups for the first 2 h. However, subjects did not 
perceive the increased heat loss or lower body temperatures. In contrast to cold 
water immersion studies, alcohol ingestion followed by mild exercise in a cold 
air environment results in enhanced heat loss and lower blood glucose levels.

PMID: 7025830 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Thermal and glycemic responses during mild exercise in +5 to -15 degrees C environments following alcohol ingestion.
Citation: Graham, T. E. (1981). Thermal and glycemic responses during mild exercise in +5 to -15 degrees C environments following alcohol ingestion. Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine, 52(9), 517-522.
conclusion neutral: In contrast to cold water immersion studies, alcohol ingestion followed by mild exercise in a cold air environment results in enhanced heat loss and lower blood glucose levels.
exclusion reason: cold exposure was via cold air, not cold water immersion
sentiment_exp: The study compared cold air exposure following alcohol ingestion to cold water immersion, but did not test cold water immersion itself, so effects are not directly applicable.
sex_representation_exp: Only men took part in this study and results were not broken down by sex.
summary: This research looked at how alcohol affects the body during exercise in cold air, not cold water. It's not directly relevant to cold water immersion therapies.

abstract:
424. Br J Clin Pharmacol. 1978 Jun;5(6):507-13. doi: 
10.1111/j.1365-2125.1978.tb01665.x.

Circulatory and alpha-adrenoceptor blocking effects of phentolamine.

Richards DA, Woodings EP, Prichard BN.

1 Intravenously administered phentolamine provoked immediate decreases in 
diastolic blood pressure but increases in heart rate and cardiac output. 2 These 
immediate circulatory effects had largely disappeared twenty minutes after 
administration and at this time phentolamine did not inhibit increases in blood 
pressure which were provoked during hand immersion in ice-cold water. 3 Log 
dose-response curves of noradrenaline induced increases in systolic and 
diastolic pressure 20 min after intravenous phentolamine were shifted to the 
right in a parallel manner compared with the curves before phentolamine 
administration. 4 It was concluded that the immediate and short acting effects 
induced by phentolamine are due to a non-specific vasodilator effect but in 
addition phentolamine causes a longer acting alpha-adrenoceptor blockade at 
vascular adrenoceptor sites. However, by producing both pre- and post-synaptic 
alpha-adrenoceptor blockade this may explain why this drug exerts only a weak 
antihypertensive effect.

DOI: 10.1111/j.1365-2125.1978.tb01665.x
PMCID: PMC1429377
PMID: 26372 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Circulatory and alpha-adrenoceptor blocking effects of phentolamine.
Citation: Richards, D. A., Woodings, E. P., & Prichard, B. N. (1978). Circulatory and alpha-adrenoceptor blocking effects of phentolamine. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 5(6), 507-513.
conclusion neutral: At this time phentolamine did not inhibit increases in blood pressure which were provoked during hand immersion in ice-cold water.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: The study showed that phentolamine did not block blood pressure changes caused by ice-cold water, so there was no significant effect related to therapeutic use of cold water immersion.
sex_representation_exp: The study does not mention the sex or gender breakdown of the participants, so we don't know if men and women were both included or analyzed separately.
summary: Although the research involves hand immersion in ice-cold water, it only uses this as a way to provoke a blood pressure response, not to study cold water immersion as a treatment or health intervention in itself.

abstract:
425. Science. 1978 Mar 10;199(4333):1093-5. doi: 10.1126/science.343250.

Endorphins: naloxone fails to alter experimental pain or mood in humans.

Grevert P, Goldstein A.

In 30 human subjects, experimental pain was produced by either ischemia or 
cold-water immersion. In a double-blind procedure, intravenous doses of up to 10 
milligrams of naloxone hydrochloride in saline were indistinguishable from 
similarly administered saline alone. There were no effects on subjective pain 
ratings, finger plethysmograph recordings, or responses to mood-state 
questionnaires. These laboratory procedures do not activate any functionally 
significant pain-attenuating or mood-altering effect of endorphins.

DOI: 10.1126/science.343250
PMID: 343250 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Endorphins: naloxone fails to alter experimental pain or mood in humans.
Citation: Grevert, P., & Goldstein, A. (1978). Endorphins: naloxone fails to alter experimental pain or mood in humans. Science, 199(4333), 1093-1095.
conclusion neutral: There were no effects on subjective pain ratings, finger plethysmograph recordings, or responses to mood-state questionnaires.
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used only as a pain stimulus
sentiment_exp: The study found that cold water immersion, when used to induce pain, did not affect pain ratings or mood—meaning no benefits or harms of cold water immersion itself were studied.
sex_representation_exp: The study doesn't specify how many men or women took part, and results are not separated by sex.
summary: This paper used cold water only to cause pain in volunteers as part of testing another drug, rather than looking at therapeutic or health effects of cold water. It doesn't tell us whether cold water immersion is helpful or harmful for therapy or wellbeing.

abstract:
426. Am J Phys Anthropol. 1975 Jul;43(1):31-8. doi: 10.1002/ajpa.1330430106.

Genetic, acclimatizational and anthropometric factors in hand cooling among 
North and South Chinese.

So JK.

The left hands of unacclimatized North Chinese (N=16) and South Chinese (N=13) 
were exposed to 5 degrees C water for 30 minutes followed by a 10 minute 
recovery period. Significant differences independent of body composition were 
found between the two samples on mean 30 minute temperature during immersion, 
time and temperature of the onset of initial CIVD (cold-induced vasodilation) at 
0.01, 0.05 and 0.10 levels respectively. The result suggests the presence of a 
genetic component in the cold responses of Continental Asian populations and the 
possibility of the presence of a clinal distribution of cold response in Asia.

DOI: 10.1002/ajpa.1330430106
PMID: 1098479 [Indexed for MEDLINE]
Title: Genetic, acclimatizational and anthropometric factors in hand cooling among North and South Chinese.
Citation: So, J.K. (1975). Genetic, acclimatizational and anthropometric factors in hand cooling among North and South Chinese. American Journal of Physical Anthropology, 43(1), 31-38.
Demographic: North and South Chinese adults, unacclimatized
conclusion neutral: Significant differences independent of body composition were found between the two samples on mean 30 minute temperature during immersion, time and temperature of the onset of initial CIVD (cold-induced vasodilation)... The result suggests the presence of a genetic component in the cold responses of Continental Asian populations...
exclusion reason: cold water immersion used as a diagnostic tool for physiological responses, not for studying therapeutic, physiological, or hormonal effects
sentiment_exp: The study measured differences in hand temperature responses to cold water, but didn't assess any benefits or harms of cold water immersion as a therapy. It was focused on genetic and physiological variations.
sex_representation_exp: The abstract doesn't specify the sex of the participants or whether results were different for men or women.
summary: Researchers compared how people from northern and southern China respond to hand cooling in icy water, finding genetic differences in blood flow responses. However, this wasn't a study of cold water therapy—just a look at natural variation in how bodies react to cold, not on any health benefits or risks.
